texts.en: The members belong to the "TRIUNFADORES" (Winners) communal bank, which is situated in the province and department of Cusco.  One member is Clara, who is 48 and married with 3 children.  She divides her time between her daily chores and her business selling clothing and periodically travels to Bolivia to buy merchandise.  She has been running her business for some years now and does well thanks to the effort she puts into it every day.  Clara sells her goods, such as sweaters, from her stall in the city centre and, in this way, is able to support her family.  She is seeking this loan to buy sweaters for her business.  The other group members are involved in graphic design and a printing business.  The members shown in the attached photo sought permission to arrive late for the meeting.  The member is grateful to those who are part of her dream in this way and is committed to make her repayments within the agreed period.

loans.use: to buy sweaters for her business.

loans.name: Kisuura Tweyombeke Group

texts.en:
Florence is a 40-year-old hardworking woman living in Kagadi, Uganda with 4 children. She has been selling onions since 2007 to generate income, and she hopes to grow her business further, even though she's challenged by bad weather. 

Florence is asking for a loan to buy onions for re-sale. 

Florence is a member of Kisuura Tweyombeke Group in which each member guarantees the other to secure a loan since they are not able to pledge securities.

loans.use: to buy onions for re-sale.

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.en:
Jeanne, age 32, is married and has three children aged between 2 and 8 years old. Two of them go to school. 

She is a farmer and she has been in business for the past six years. Her husband is also a farmer. 

With the loan from Kiva, she would like to buy that cow in the photo while the man in the photo is the one who is selling the cow to her.With the profits from the business she wished to increase her savings and to pay school fees of her children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more cows for rearing.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Teresiah would like to build a permanent cowshed and buy animal feeds

loans.name: Folole

texts.en: A plantation is a common source of income in Samoa. There are hundreds of families that have survived the daily expenses on crops produced on their plantations. Although it is a common source of income Folole insists that her business is likely to succeed because she has a way with knowing what is good and not good for her crops. In Samoa, it is not necessarily the cheaper crops that are sold but the biggest. Folole works six days a week on expanding her plantation and working on ways to better the quality of her crops.

loans.use: to purchase equipment for improving crops fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Jose Antonio

texts.en:
I have had a business for four years where I sell basic goods. Now I need to buy more products to supply the needs of my neighbors. With the income I get from this store, I help to cover family expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo 4 años de tener mi negocio donde vendo productos de consumo popular. ahora necesito comprar mas producto para poder suplir las necesidades de mis vecinos. Cn los ingresosue percibo de esta pulperia a yudo a cubril gastos familiares

loans.use: To buy meat, dairy products, soft drinks, sugar, rice, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To boost his business

loans.name: Kamran

texts.en:
Kamran is a low-income, vulnerable person. He is 45, married with three children, and lives in Saatli in the south-central plains area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Kamran rents a small shop in the local bazaar of Saatli town where he sells souvenirs, toys for children, etc. The business is very successful but needs some investment of capital to increase the daily turnover.

Kamran has no collateral that would allow him to apply to the commercial banks for a loan to provide capital for his little shop. That's why he has applied to Normicro's Saatli branch for a US$ 500 loan. This loan would allow him to buy bigger quantities of goods for resale and provide better for the necessities of life for his children.

loans.use: To increase the variety of goods

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina Mercedes Florentin Lopes, 51, is a micro- entrepreneur from Valle Apua – Lambaré, Paraguay. She is married to Alfonso Escurra, a shoemaker. Together they have five adult children.

Lina owns a despensa, or small convenience store, which she runs out of her house. She began this business with a loan she obtained from the Foundation. Since its inception she has been doing very well. In addition to what she earns from the despensa, her husband also helps with household costs.

Lina is requesting a loan to purchase a more diverse array of merchandise, such as: sugar, flour, oil, soaps, sodas and coffee. She currently belongs to a committee of women in Kuña Katypyry. This committee consists of 16 women and is designed to provide support for each member in running their business and paying their loans.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Suciastini

texts.id:
Suciantini lives with her husband and her infant child. As a newly-wed, for now she is living with her husband's parents. To help her driver husband in generating income, Suciantini raises, breeds and fattens pigs. She got her money to start the business from her husband's work as a driver and her parents’ in-law. Since the business is developing and creating enough profit, Suciantini would like to increase the number of her pigs with capital help from DINARI which will be used to buy 2 breeders, feed supply, and healthcare for her pigs. From one breeder which she has raised for 6 months, she can have 18 piggies sold for Rp. 4.500.00,- with net income for six months of Rp. 1.500.000,-. In the future she expects the increase of number of her breeder she raised will increase her income as well.

Translated from Indonesian by Iman Persada, Kiva volunteer.

Saat ini Suciastini tinggal bersama suaminya dan seorang anak yang masih balita. Karena baru saja membina rumah tangga, maka untuk saat ini tinggal bersama orang tua dari suaminya.Untuk menambah pendapatan suaminya yang bekerja sebagai sopir, Suciastini memelihara satu ekor induk dan satu ekor pengemukan. Modal awal yang dipergunakan untuk memulai usaha beternak babi ini adalah hasil jerih payah dari pekerjaan suaminya dan bantuan dari mertuanya. Karena semakin berkembang dan juga usaha ini mendatangkan keuntungan yang lumayan Suciastinipun ingin menambah jumlah babinya menjadi lebih banyak lagi dengan bantuan modal dari DINARI dipakai untuk membeli dua ekor induk babi dan juga untuk persediaan pakan dan kesehatan ternaknya. Dari satu ekor induk yang sudah dipeliharanya selama ini dalam 6 bulan menghasilkan 18 ekor bibit yang dijual dengan harga Rp.4.500.000,- dengan keuntungan bersih dalam enam bulan mencapai Rp1.500.0000,- harapan untuk kedepannya dengan bertambahnya jumlah induk babi yang dipelihara maka akan bertambah pula jumlah pendapatannya.

loans.use: To buy pig breeder

loans.name: Nora

texts.es:
Nora G. Flores is the mother of four school-aged children and is married to a haulage contractor. She works as a vender in seasonal markets, which means that depending on the time of the year, she buys her products and sells them in the principle markets of the city. Her high sales seasons come generally at the holidays near the end of the year, at artesanal markets, at Carnival (similar to Mardi Gras), and during the feast of San Juan.

Along with this activity, Nora dedicates her free time to making slips and bolts of cloth, which she subsequently sells by walking around the markets and plazas in her area. In addition, taking advantage of all the trips that she makes to buy and sell merchandise, Nora sees to buying replacement parts for electrical and home appliances, an activity which over time and little by little has become a wholesale business.

Nora needs money in order to strengthen her seasonal market stall, since the season of Carnival is approaching as well as the beginning of the school term, which are both good times for Nora to generate strong income.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

Nora G. Flores es madre de 4 hijos, todos en edad escolar, y casado con un transportista, se dedica al comercio de mercadería de temporada, es decir, dependiendo la época del año, ella compra sus productos y vende en las principales ferias de la ciudad. Sus temporadas de venta alta generalmente son las fiestas de fin de año, alasitas, carnavales y la fiesta de San Juan.

Paralelamente a esta actividad, Nora en sus ratos libres se dedica a la confección de enaguas, y centros de tela, las que posteriormente las vende deambulando en las ferias y plazas de su zona. De igual forma, aprovechando sus viajes que realiza tanto para vender como para la compra de mercadería, Nora se encarga de comprar repuestos para electrodomésticos, y línea blanca, actividad que poco a poco y con el tiempo ya la ha convertido en mayorista.

Nora requiere de dinero para poder dar más fuerza a su puesto de venta de mercadería de temporada, ya que próximamente se acercan las fiestas de carnavales y el inicio de clases, que son una buena oportunidad para ela de generar buenos ingresos.

loans.use: To strengthen her seasonal market stall.

loans.name: Muhammad

texts.id:
David sells young coconut drinks at the Kerobokan Primary School in the morning, and at the Thomas Aquino School in the evening throughout the school year with the help of his scooter. He makes $10 daily in profits. In Bali, he spends $2 a day and rents a room with a monthly rent of $22.50. He supports his wife, who lives in Java with their grandchild. He will use the loan to expand his business.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Joan, Kiva volunteer.

David berjualan es kelapa muda di Sekolah Dasar (SD) I Kerobokan pada pagi hari dan di Sekolah Thomas Aquino pada sore harinya. Hal itu dia lakukan setiap hari, selama hari – hari sekolah berlangsung. Dalam melakukan pekerjaannya sarana transportasi yang digunakan adalah sepeda motor. Per hari dia memperoleh keuntungan sebesar Rp 100.000,00. Modal yang dia peroleh akan dia pakai untuk menambah omzet penjualannya. Tanggungannya adalah seorang isteri yang tinggal di Jawa bersama cucu. Di Bali dia menyewa sebuah kamar dengan biaya Rp 225.000,00 per bulan dengan biaya hidup per harinya Rp 20.000,00.

loans.use: To increase selling turnover

loans.name: Yesuamala Ib Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rose N.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to purchase a sewing machine. Rose is 37 years old and is married. Her husband is a taxi driver. She has 4 children ranging from age 4 to 17 and her children go to school. Each week, Rose makes approximately UGX 38900 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to cater for her children's needs. Rose has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to buy clothes and threads and the loan was paid back on time.

Rose is joined in her small group by Mary N., Annet N., Zula N., and Rashida N.. Mary N. has a canteen business and wants to add to the business. Annet N. is currently operating a restaurant business and wants a loan to purchase more furniture. Zula N. operates a business in poultry farming and wants to buy chicks. Rashida N. is currently in the business of charcoal sales and is requesting a loan to purchase charcoal in bulk.

loans.use: To add to tailoring business

loans.name: Kjghk's Group

texts.en: jkhfgkjhg

loans.use: gkhjgkjhg

loans.name: Elvisa

texts.en: Elvisa was born in 1982 and is not married. She lives with her grandmother and grandfather in a small suburb of Gračanica. Elvisa works and her monthly salary is 400 KM. Her grandfather has monthly pension in the amount of 280 KM. This is Elvisa's first loan at MCO WWI in the amount of 900 KM ($725).  Elvisa will buy seeds for sowing with this loan. Her wish is to try with her own food production in order to generate more income for her family.

loans.use: To buy seeds.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.es:
Vilma is a creative and hard-working woman who learned to embroider only by watching others and without the aid of a teacher. Thanks to her ability and her effort she's been able to help improve her family's quality of life and now, with festival season approaching her valley, she knows that demand for her products will soon increase. For this reason she wishes to acquire a larger quantity of threads and fabrics to be able to meet demand for the orders that are sure to come.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Vilma es una mujer muy creativa y trabajadora que aprendió a bordar sólo observando y sin la necesidad de una maestra de manera continua. Gracias a su desempeño y a su esfuerzo ha podido contribuir a mejorar la calidad de vida de su hogar y ahora que se acerca las festividades en todos su valle sabe que la demanda se va a incrementar dentro de poco y por esa razón desea adquirir mayor cantidad de telas e hilos para prever los pedidos que está segura vendrán.

loans.use: Purchase thread and fabric / Compra de tela e hilos en mayor cantidad.

loans.name: Sokhon

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhon A. lives in Prey Dong Teok Village in Kampong Speu Province. She is currently in the business of rice plantation. Her husband, Mr. Saron Mich, is a government officer who gets only a small salary to support his family. They have nine children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory, while three others are attending the local school. The remaining four are staying at home because they are too young to work or enroll in school.

In order to improve her family conditions, Mrs. Sokhon A. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. Last year, Mrs. Sokhon A. obtained a loan from Acleda Bank to cure a disease because one of her family members got typhoid and she needed to spend $200 to get them cured. Mrs. Sokhon A. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding in order to meet the economic needs of the family.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy E. lives in Okokhuo, Edo state, Nigeria. She is 53 years old and married with 5 children. She owns a piece of land where she grows plantains, pineapples, and other farm produce. She has been into farming since 1990. After harvesting the pineapples and plantains, she sells the farm produce in the local market in her community. She is a LAPO client. She needs the loan amount of US$ 450 to buy more plantain and pineapple suckers for planting.

loans.use: To buy plantain and pineapple suckers for planting

loans.name: Las Frutillitas Group

texts.en:
The Las Frutillitas Group ("The Little Strawberries) is maD. up of 14 people, all of whom have been together for several loan cycles. Rosely R. organized the group in 2007 and the group decided to call themselves Las Frutillitas, because the name brought back memories of good luck at other microfinance institutions. Most of the women in the group have stable businesses, while others are public employees. Wilma, Josefa, Sussy, Julia, Patricia and N. all sell food (rice, cakes, prepared meals, salchipapas (French fries with hot dog slices), and sweets), Erick works as a driver, Encarnación sells macramé crafts, Julia and Rosely sell shawls, Denis works as a security guard, Rosmery sells knitted goods, Wendy fixes ovens, and N. Antonia sells bottles. Most of the group members plans to use this loan to buy more merchandise to sell, or to buy ingredients for cooking. Las Frutillitas have never been late on their payments, so they were approved for this, their fourth loan. All of the group members are committed to repaying their loan, so that they can keep working with AgroCapital. Translated and elaborated by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Fellow

GRUPO CONFORMADO POR 14 PERSONAS QUE SE ESTABLECIERON DESD. EL PRIMER CICLO, EL GRUPO LAS FRUTILLITAS EMPIEZA EN EL AÑO 2007 DOND. LA SRA ROSELY R. CONFORMO EL GRUPO Y TODAS LAS SOCIAS LE DIERON EL NOMBRE D. LAS FRUTILLITAS POR QUE ESTE NOMBRE LES TRAJO MUY BUENOS RECUERSOS Y SUERTE EN OTRAS INSTITUCIONES

LA MAYORIA D. LAS SOCIAS TIENEN NEGOCIOS ESTABLES Y LA OTRA PARTE SON EMPLEADOS PUBLICOS POR LO QUE NUNCA EL GRUPO ENTRO EN MORA NI TUVO RETRASOS, POR LO QUE SE LES CONCEDIO EL PRESTAMO PARA ESTE CUARTO CICLO.

TODAS COMPROMETIENDOSE A LA CANCELACION D. SU DEUDA, PARA PODER SEGUIR TRABAJANDO CON LA INSTITUCION.

loans.use: Buy more merchandise and ingredients for cooking

loans.name: Rolando

texts.es:
El señor Rolando N. tiene 32 años es soltero, él se dedica a la venta de filtros de aceite para autos y motos, al igual que lubricantes y aceites de distintas marcas. Su negocio está ubicado sobre una avenida muy importante y con este trabajo esta construyendo para su casa en el terreno de su madre.

Sueña con tener algún día un taller mecánico en el mismo pueda realizar los cambios de filtro y aceites.
texts.en:
Rolando N. is 32 years old and is single. He sells oil filters for cars and motorbikes, as well as different types of lubricants and oils. His business is on a very important road and with this job he is building his house on his mother's land.

He dreams of one day having his own mechanics garage where he could carry out oil and filter changes.


Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy oils, filters and lubricants/Para la compra de aceites, filtros y lubricantes.

loans.name: Albina

texts.es:
La señora Albina Z. Pérez  tiene 62 años y pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres al Progreso, vive en la calle Tomás Zolano Mz 7 lote 13 segunda etapa Victor Raul del distrito del Porvenir, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudió hasta tercero de primaria y tuvo que dejar de estudiar para trabajar porque no tenía apoyo ya que fue huérfana.
Se casó de 17 años con el señor Víctor Villacorta, con quien tuvo 5 hijos, uno fallecido, todos sus hijos ya están separados, pero tiene a su cargo un nieto.
Compró una vaca y empezó a vender leche, ahora tiene 4 vacas de las cuales vende leche, sus animales los tiene en un lugar llamado El Carmelo en Virú, pero la leche la trae a Trujillo.
Con el primer préstamo de 300 soles cancelados en 4 cuotas compró comida para sus animales. (Melaza y forraje).
Con este crédito de 500 soles que será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará 22 gallinas ponedoras y comida para vaca.
Albina sueña con hacer en un terreno grande un pozo tubular.
texts.en:
Albina Z. P., 62, belongs to the Mujeres al Progreso ("Women Forging Ahead") community bank. She lives in the Peruvian "departamento" of La Libertad. She dropped out of school after only three years because she had to work, something about which she had no choice because there was no-one to support her when she was orphaned. At 17, she married Victor Villacorta with whom she has 5 children, one of whom has died. Her children no longer live with her but she's raising a grandson. She bought a cow to start a milk business; she now has 4 cows and sells the milk they produce. She keeps the cows in a place called El Carmelo in Viru, but she brings the milk to Trujillo [to sell]. With her first 300-soles loan, which she repaid in 4 installments, she bought feed for her cows. (Molasses and fodder.) With this 500-soles loan, to be repaid in 4 installments, she will buy 22 hens and food for the cows. Albina dreams of building a tube well one day.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy hens and feed for livestock business.

loans.name: Arceli

texts.en:
Arceli has a small poultry business in her humble community of Barangay Ballacong Ilagan, Isabela, where most of the settlers are engaged primarily in agricultural businesses. She is married and has two children. Arceli loves her family very much and she is motivated to work hard for them. 

She raises commercial chickens and sells them when they reach 40-45 days, and she earns PHP100 - PHP120 per kilo. She makes sure that she does not run out of stocks by buying some chicks even when there is still inventory of chickens ready for sale. The members of the family take part in managing the business.  

Arceli is asking for a loan of PHP5,000 in order to increase her income because at the moment, her earnings are limited due to lack of capital. Increased income will mean additional resources to support the basic needs of her family and her children’s education. Arceli further shared that the education of her children will bring them security in the future.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Khursheda

texts.en:
Khursheda is married with three children. Hers is an average family from Istaravshan, Tajikistan. However, Khursheda is a unique entrepreneur. She has been selling shoes in the central city market for about 3 years, running her own small venture successfully. She also sells reels of thread, needles and other items for sewing. The secret of her success is simple: she tries to not only let her customers know the benefits of her products—she also gives them a sense of relationship which brings them back again and again. However, she doesn’t want to stop where she is now with her venture. Khursheda is seeking a loan of 3500 Somoni to restock the merchandise in her store for the winter season. We believe that Khursheda’s desire to excel in pleasing her customers will secure her further success and encourage new customers to buy from her.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and the most famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina (Avicenna). The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing winter boots for men

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Năm  37 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2000. Khi mới tham gia Quỹ nguồn thu nhập của gia đình chị năm chủ yếu dựa vào chăn nuôi và trồng trọt. Hiện tại ngoài chăn nuôi chị Năm còn đi thu mua đỗ, lạc của bà con để bán lại cho người tiêu dùng, còn chồng chị đi làm thuê . Với thu nhập 3.500.000đ/ tháng kinh tế gia đình chị Năm đang ngày càng ổn định hơn.
Vòng vốn tới chị Năm mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn cho công việc thu mua đỗ, lạc...
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Năm, 37 years old, has participated in the TYM Fund since 2000. When she first joined the Fund, her family depended on raising animals and growing crops for their income. Today, in addition to raising animals, Mrs. Năm also buys beans and peanuts in bulk from local farmers and sells them to consumers, and her husband works as a hired laborer. With their current income of about 3,500,000 VND per month, the financial condition of her family is steadily becoming more secure. In the next round of lending, Mrs. Năm hopes to borrow 10,000,000 VND (575 USD) to invest in her business selling beans and peanuts.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bean and peanut sales

loans.name: Bollo Liguéye Group

texts.fr: Mékhé (http://www.sem-fund.org/mekhe.php), est célèbre de par sa position commerciale stratégique (Chemin de fer) et ses riches potentialités artisanales (Chaussures & Vannerie). C'est une région fortement agricole et l'activité économique se résume au  commerce, à l'élevage, à  l'agriculture, à l'artisanat, etc. Ce qui a poussé les femmes du groupement de Bollo Liguéye a évolué dans le secteur du commerce. Certaines sont des vendeuses « ambulantes », d’autres disposent d’étals sur le marché. Connaissant bien le secteur  de l’évolution des marchés, elles voudraient  continuer à progresser dans ce domaine de commerce avec un projet de microcrédit en achetant de la marchandise et en la revendant (tissu, bijoux, chaussures, produits artisanaux).
texts.en:
Mékhé (http://www.sem-fund.org/mekhe.php), is famous for its strategic commercial location (on the railway line) and its potential wealth in handmade articles (shoes, woven baskets). This is a very agricultural region and economic activities are in buying and selling, livestock-raising, agriculture, handicrafts, etc. This has encouraged the women of the Bollo Liguéye group to go into commercial activities. Some are door-to-door saleswomen, others have displays at the market. Quite familiar with the evolution of this marketing sector, they would like to continue to progress in this domain with a micro-credit project involving buying and re-selling goods (cloth, jewelry, shoes, handicrafts).

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying and selling goods

loans.name: Flor

texts.es: Flor tiene 46 años, vive con su esposo y sus cuatro hijas en la casa que terminaron de construir hace poco tiempo atrás. Ella se considera una gran empresaria dentro de las líneas de belleza donde trabaja hace 15 años, siempre cubre sus metas de venta, obteniendo premios por su buen desempeño, lo cual la motiva a seguir trabajando por mucho más tiempo y tener proyección a futuro en base a esta actividad, pues le agrada conocer a muchas personas y relacionarse con gran diversidad de clientas ofreciéndoles productos de belleza. Esta actividad la realiza todos los días a partir de las  8 de la mañana, sale a visitar a sus clientas con sus diversos catálogos y en las tardes solo se dedica a la distribución de los pedidos y las cobranzas, que siempre es lo más tedioso para ella. En el futuro Flor desea tener un bazar en su casa para exponer sus productos de belleza y que estén al alcance de todas las mujeres de su localidad. Este es su dieciochoavo préstamo, lo que la hace una cliente fiel de MFP, pues es una de las clientes fundadoras de la institución en esta zona. Con el dinero solicitado comprará más productos de belleza en promoción, lo que favorecen a toda promotora para incrementar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Flor is 46 years old and lives with her husband and four daughters in the house they built a while back. She is considered an astute businesswoman with regard to the lines of beauty products she has sold for the last 15 years. She consistently makes her sales goals, winning prizes for her good performance. This motivates her to continue working and to develop future sales projections. She enjoys being involved with her diverse customer base and being able to offer them beauty products. Every day, starting at 8:00 in the morning, she leaves with a variety of catalogs to visit her customers. Late afternoons are dedicated to the distribution of orders and bill collection, something that is always more tedious for her. In the future, Flor wants to have a shop at her house to display her beauty products, one that would be accessible to all the neighborhood women. This is her eighteenth loan, making her a loyal customer of MFP as well as one of the founders of this institution in her area. With the requested funds she will buy more beauty products on sale, something favored by any businessperson to increase profits.

Translated from Spanish by Lisette Artiga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Doris Amalia

texts.es:
Doris es socia del Bancomunal señor de los Milagros.
Doris es conviviente, tiene 21 años, tiene  dos hijos gemelos de 9 meses.
Doris termino el colegio y se puso a trabajar en una imprenta  por un año, le iba bien, pero salió embarazada,  su amiga le ofreció para que vendiera zapatos, que ella confecciona, entonces Doris vio la oportunidad que necesitaba y ahora se dedica a la venta de zapatos en su casa.  
Desde que está en Finca Doris aprendió a ser responsable, puntual con sus pagos, ella ve en el Bancomunal que las socias son solidarias entre ellas.  
Doris necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles para la compra de zapatos, sandalias 
El sueño de Doris es tener una tienda de calzados en su casa.
texts.en:
Doris is a member of the communal bank called Senor de los Milagros. She is 21 years old and married with twin 9 month old babies. Doris finished highschool and went to work in a printing shop for a year. The job was good, but she needed to leave once she was pregnant. A friend suggested that Doris start selling shoes that she was making. And so Doris saw the opportunity she needed and now she sells shoes from her house. Since she has been working with the communal bank, she has learned to be responsible and she is timely with her payments. She sees that there is a lot of solidarity between the bank's members. Doris will use the loan to purchase shoes and sandals. Her dream is to one day have her own shoe shop set up in her house.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase shoes and sandals which she sells from her home

loans.name: Lole

texts.en:
Lole L., 38, is married with 8 children. She has 4 years of experience in the retail business. She sells to the general public 7 days per week. This is her first loan with SPBD. She will use the loan to purchase rice, flour, sugar, onions, salt, seasoning oil, laundry soap and powder, beverages, snacks like bongos twities, chilly chocs, ice pops, ice cream and lollies to sell. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 291 Tala.

SPBD loans are Lole's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase rice, flour, sugar, onions, salt, seasoning oil, laundry soap and powder, beverages, and snacks to sell.

loans.name: Gladis Del Carmen

texts.es: Gladis del Carmen C. D. A. D. 41 años D. edad, resiD. en Soyapango junto a sus dos hijos mayores D. edad, los cuales estudian en la universidad y su esposo que trabaja como comerciante. Gladis se dedica a vender ropa en el mercado D. Soyapango, ella comercializa todos los días su producto con el fin D. poder contribuir junto a su esposo a solventar los gastos del hogar, ya que sus dos hijos asisten a la universidad y esto les genera un gasto bastante alto, el cual están dispuestos a pagar por el bienestar D. sus hijos. Ella tiene ocho años D. vender ropa y posee muchos clientes los cuales son muy fieles a ella, es por esto que Gladis solícita un préstamo, para que a través del cual pueda aumentar los productos D. su negocio con el fin D. poder incrementar sus ventas, solventando las exigencias D. sus clientes y obteniendo nuevos y así D. esta manera obtener más ganancias las cuales contribuyan a la economía familiar.
texts.en:
Gladis del Carmen C. D. A. is 41 and lives in Soyapango with her two adult children. They are in college, and her husband works as a salesman. Gladis sells clothing in the market in Soyapango. She sells her products every day with the goal of helping her husband pay for their home's expenses since their two children are in college and this generates a rather high cost. They are willing to pay for this for the well-being of their children. She has sold clothing for eight years and has many customers who are very loyal to her. This is why Gladis is requesting a loan, so she can increase the amount of products she has as well as her sales. She will then be able to meet her customers' demand and obtain more customers so she can earn more profits and contribute to the family finances.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase more clothing
